awd_titl_txt: AGS-PRF: Improving Space Weather and Space Climate Predictions by Investigating and Modeling Surface Flux Transport on the Sun
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this two-year postgraduate fellowship research project is to improve the forecasting capabilities of space climate and space weather models. Solar storms, which are one component of space weather, have the potential to do significant damage to satellites, power grids, and humans in space.  Prediction of these eruptions from the solar surface is in its infancy and this project vastly improve the basis of the predictive models. The goals are to improve understanding of the flows on the Sun's surface, the interaction of these flows with the magnetic field, and how the flows combine with the magnetic field to impact the Sun's eleven year cycle and its dynamo. One very important task project is to produce the most accurate full-Sun maps of the magnetic field on the surface (the photosphere) to date. This is very timely as this model and its resulting products will be immediately useful to forecasters such as those at NOAA/SWPC (National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administrations Space Weather Prediction Center). The Principle Investigator of this project is an early career scientist from an underrepresented minority who will work with undergraduate (REU) students to carry out the work.

This project is based on the Advective Flux Transport (AFT) model, developed by the PI and her collaborators at the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR). This is a surface flux transport model that advects the magnetic flux on the sun using observational data for of near-surface flows. It can also assimilate magnetogram data for increased realism. Some of the stated goals of this project are to promote AFT as a cross discipline bridge, and to improve the space weather and climate forecasting capabilities of the model. This will be done, in part, by providing synchronic maps as magnetic source data, interfacing with dynamo models to connect with internal dynamics, investigating active region source properties, incorporating complex far-side active region emergence and investigate ever more sophisticated data assimilation techniques. Accomplishing these goals will help provide the knowledge needed to reproduce a range of cycle amplitudes and variations, potentially including the recovery from a Maunder-type Grand minimum and improve our understanding of the role of surface dynamics in modulating the solar activity cycle which will extend the predictive capability of flux transport models.

por.por_cntn:
Overview

Understanding and predicting the Sun's variability is vital to protecting our nation's assets. Advance knowledge of this variability is essential in the planning of space-based missions as it has a direct effect on satellite orbital decay. Furthermore, space weather can disrupt power grids. With predictions, power companies can be better prepared for these events (e.g. they can plan for how many extra transformers to have on backup).

 The primary goal of this project was to observe and model the transport of the Sun's surface magnetic field in order to investigate its role in producing solar cycle variability, space climate, and space weather. This was done using the Advective Flux Transport (AFT) model, a predictive surface flux transport model that simulates the evolution of magnetic field at the Sun's surface.

 The project produced the following results:

(1) An improved weighting function for the data assimilation of magnetograms into AFT.
(2) Automatic detection algorithm for finding newly emerging or growing active regions on the far-side of the Sun using STEREO/EUVI images. (Figure 1)
(3) Version of AFT which incorporates far-side active regions, producing more accurate maps of the magnetic field at the solar surface.  (Figure 2)
(4) Prediction for the timing and amplitude of Solar Cycle 25: Cycle 25 will be the weakest cycle on record in the last hundred years and we will have another long extended solar minimum that will not end until late 2020 or early 2021. (Figure 3)
(5) The AFT model can be combined with models of magnetic topology and heating to yield realistic estimates for the decay of active region radiances with time.
(6) AFT data can be combined with a magnetofrictional model to determine the shear along polarity inversion line, which can then be used to energize the magnetic fields in coronal simulations. This was found to change the shape and morphology of the large scale streamers to be more consistent with the eclipse.
(7) Maps of the horizontal large-scale convective flows (giant cells) from July 2010 to July 2018. (Figure 4) 
(8) The development of website for sharing knowledge, love of the Sun, and data with both the general public and their fellow scientists alike.

Intellectual Merit

This project provided novel measurements of flows in the solar surface and interior, improving our understanding of surface dynamics. This project also enabled advances to the AFT model, improving the accuracy and predictive range of AFT as well as producing the most accurate full-Sun maps of the photospheric magnetic field. These maps were used in conjunction with coronal models to produce realistic estimates for the decay of active region radiances with time and the shape and morphology of the global coronal magnetic fields. AFT also produced prediction for the timing and amplitude of Solar Cycle 25, which is essential in the planning of space-based missions.

Broader Impacts

This project provided the PI, Dr. Lisa Upton, a female postdoctoral researcher, mentoring, with an opportunity to conduct research, and extensive career development. Through this project, Dr. Upton was able to participate in several Education and public outreach activities, such as: mentoring undergraduate and graduate students, organizing and running the SPD Student Poster Competition, giving public lectures and demonstrations, as well as developing a website. This project also enabled international and multidisciplinary collaborations which connected the internal dynamics of the sun to the evolution of the magnetic field at the surface and into the corona. Results from this project were presented in 4 peer-reviewed journal articles, 13 conference preceding, several smaller workshops, and 4 invited colloquiums.

Images (1 of )
  • Active regions detected in STEREO/EUVI 304 images (A/C) are compared with the corresponding AFT maps (B/D), which only include near-side information. The differences indicate additional far-side, active region emergence (E), which are inserted into the AFT model (F).
    Lisa Upton
    Public Domain
    Lisa A Upton
    STEREO 304 automated active region detection
  • The AFT Baseline with data assimilation (top panel) and the AFT Baseline with the integration of the STEREO/EUVI 304 inferred far side active regions (bottom). The addition of several newly emerged active regions and additional growth of existing active regions can be clearly seen on the right.
    Lisa Upton
    Public Domain
    Lisa A Upton
    AFT Baseline for Oct 6th, 2013
  • This figure shows the polar field strength as measured from the axial dipole moment (red) along with the AFT predictions (2016 in the lighter blue and 2018 in the darker blue). These results suggest that Cycle 25 will be slightly weaker than Cycle 24.
    Lisa Upton
    Public Domain
    Lisa A Upton
    AFT 2018 predictions and observations.
  • The latitudinal (top left) and longitudinal (bottom left) velocities of the large-scale convective flows. The Reynolds Stress (top right) indicates an equatorward flux of angular momentum at high latitudes. The kinetic helicity (bottom right) is consistent with expectations.
    David Hathaway
    Lisa A Upton
    Giant Cell Flows.
